sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using inverse matrices
message_1:
Find the solution to the system of linear equations using inverse matrices:

2x + 3y = 7

4x - 2y = -2
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations using inverse matrices, we first write the given system in matrix form AX = B, where A is the matrix of coefficients, X is the matrix of variables, and B is the matrix of constants.

A = | 2  3 |
    | 4 -2 |

X = | x |
    | y |

B = |  7 |
    | -2 |

Now, we find the inverse of matrix A, denoted as A^(-1). To do this, we first find the determinant of A.

Determinant of A = (2 * -2) - (3 * 4) = -4 - 12 = -16

Since the determinant is non-zero, the inverse of A exists. Now, we find A^(-1) using the formula:

A^(-1) = (1/determinant) * adjoint(A)

The adjoint of A is obtained by swapping the diagonal elements and changing the sign of the off-diagonal elements:

Adjoint(A) = | -2 -3 |
                     | -4  2 |

Now, multiply the adjoint of A by the reciprocal of the determinant:

A^(-1) = (-1/16) * | -2 -3 |
                              | -4  2 |

A^(-1) = | 1/8   3/16 |
               | 1/4  -1/8 |

Now, we multiply A^(-1) by B to get the solution matrix X:

X = A^(-1) * B

X = | 1/8   3/16 | * |  7 |
       | 1/4  -1/8 |    | -2 |

X = | (1/8 * 7) + (3/16 * -2) |
       | (1/4 * 7) + (-1/8 * -2) |

X = | 7/8 - 3/8 |
       | 7/4 + 1/4 |

X = | 1/2 |
       | 2   |

So, the solution to the system of linear equations is x = 1/2 and y = 2.
